original_data.question: A 2-day-old infant male is brought to the emergency department with a 5-hour history of vomiting and irritability. He was born at home and had unreliable prenatal care because his parents have been experiencing housing instability. About a day after birth, he started to become lethargic and was feeding poorly. His parents thought that he might just be tired so they put him to bed; however, by the next morning he started to vomit and act extremely irritable. On presentation, he is found to have nuchal rigidity and bulging fontanelles. Based on this presentation, appropriate cultures are obtained and he is placed on empiric antibiotics. After all cultures grow out the same gram-positive bacteria, the patient is narrowed to penicillin G. Which of the following is a characteristic of the most likely organism that is causing this patient's symptoms?

options.A: Enlarges hemolytic area of Staphylococcus aureus
options.C: Produces toxin that increases cAMP levels
options.D: Tumbling motility in broth at 22 degrees

model_response: The patient most likely has early-onset sepsis, which is most commonly caused by group B streptococci (GBS). GBS is part of the normal flora of the gastrointestinal tract and female genital tract. It can cause early-onset (within 7 days) or late-onset (after 7 days) sepsis. Early-onset sepsis presents with poor feeding, lethargy, hypotonia, and irritability. It can progress to respiratory distress, hypoperfusion, and shock. Late-onset sepsis presents with meningitis. GBS is a gram-positive bacillus that is beta-hemolytic and optochin-sensitive. It can be distinguished from other streptococci by its growth in 5% NaCl. GBS produces a polysaccharide capsule that is antiphagocytic. It can also produce a variety of exotoxins, but the exact role of these toxins in pathogenesis is unclear. The lipooligosaccharide of GBS has endotoxic activity, but this is not characteristic of all GBS strains. The most virulent strains of GBS produce a C5a peptidase that inhibits the chemotactic response of neutrophils. The C5a peptidase of GBS is an example of a virulence factor that inhibits the complement system. The A and B toxins of Clostridium tetani are neurotoxins that increase cAMP and cGMP levels, respectively. Bacillus anthracis produces a toxin that increases cAMP levels. The A and B toxins of Corynebacterium diphtheriae are neurotoxins that increase cAMP and cGMP levels, respectively. The A toxin of Bordetella pertussis is a neurotoxin that increases cAMP levels. The A toxin of B. anthracis is a neurotoxin that increases cAMP levels. The A toxin of B. cereus is a neurotoxin that increases cAMP levels. The A toxin of B. thuringiensis is a neurotoxin that increases cGMP levels. The A toxin of B. pseudomallei is a neurotoxin that increases cGMP levels. The A toxin of B. pertussis is a neurotoxin that increases cGMP levels. The A toxin of C. difficile is a neurotoxin that increases cGMP levels. The A toxin of C. tetani is a neurotoxin that increases cGMP levels. The A toxin of C. sordellii is a neurotoxin that increases cGMP levels. The A toxin of C. botulinum is a neurotoxin that blocks the release of acetylcholine. The A toxin of C. difficile is a neurotoxin that blocks the release of acetylcholine. The A toxin of C. perfringens is a neurotoxin that blocks the release of acetylcholine. The A toxin of C. sordellii is a neurotoxin that blocks the release of acetylcholine. The A toxin of C. botulinum is a neurotoxin that blocks the release of acetylcholine. The A toxin of C. tetani is a neurotoxin that blocks the release of acetylcholine. The A toxin of C. difficile is a neurotoxin that blocks the release of acetylcholine. The A toxin of C. perfringens is a neurotoxin that blocks the release of acetylcholine. The A toxin of C. sordellii is a neurotoxin that blocks the release of acetylcholine. The A toxin of C. botulinum is a neurotoxin that blocks the release of acetylcholine. The A toxin of C. tetani is a neurotoxin that blocks the release of acetylcholine. The A toxin of C. difficile is a neurotoxin that blocks the release of acetylcholine. The A toxin of C.

question_entities.definition: A child between 1 and 23 months of age.
A person who belongs to the sex that normally produces sperm. The term is used to indicate biological sex distinctions, cultural gender role distinctions, or both.
Hospital department responsible for the administration and provision of immediate medical or surgical care to the emergency patient.
Abnormal or excessive excitability with easily triggered anger, annoyance, or impatience.
The event of being born.
Aspects of peoples' living conditions that may and can impact people's health and/or well-being. These factors may be physical (e.g., housing quality) or social circumstances (e.g., living alone).

Security metadata observation value used to indicate that the veracity or trustworthiness of an IT resource (data, information object, service, or system capability) for a specified purpose of use is perceived to be or deemed by policy to be inadequate.
Care provided the pregnant woman in order to prevent complications, and decrease the incidence of maternal and prenatal mortality.
Persons functioning as natural, adoptive, or substitute parents. The heading includes the concept of parenthood as well as preparation for becoming a parent.
Living facilities for humans.
Occurring or done each day.
The process of giving birth to one or more offspring.
Characterized by a lack of vitality or energy.
Interruption or disruption of the intake of food/nutrition.
Persons functioning as natural, adoptive, or substitute parents. The heading includes the concept of parenthood as well as preparation for becoming a parent.
The state of weariness following a period of exertion, mental or physical, characterized by a decreased capacity for work and reduced efficiency to respond to stimuli.
Equipment on which one may lie and sleep, especially as used to care for the hospital patient.
The time period between dawn and noon.
The forcible expulsion of the contents of the STOMACH through the MOUTH.
Abnormal or excessive excitability with easily triggered anger, annoyance, or impatience.
To show or display; the act of presenting something to sight or view: how something looks.

Resistance of the extensor muscles of the neck to being bent forwards (i.e., impaired neck flexion) as a result of muscle spasm of the extensor muscles of the neck. Nuchal rigidity is not a fixed rigidity. Nuchal rigidity has been used as a bedside test for meningism, although its sensitivity for this purpose has been debated. [PMID:12060874]
Membranous areas between cranial bones in a newborn that appear elevated or full.
To show or display; the act of presenting something to sight or view: how something looks.
A collective expression for all behavior patterns acquired and socially transmitted through symbols. Culture includes customs, traditions, and language.

Substances naturally produced by microorganisms or their derivatives that selectively target microorganisms not humans. Antibiotics kill or inhibit the growth of microorganisms by targeting components of the microbial cell absent from human cells, including bacterial cell walls, cell membrane, and 30S or 50S ribosomal subunits. These substances are used in the treatment of bacterial and other microbial infections.
A collective expression for all behavior patterns acquired and socially transmitted through symbols. Culture includes customs, traditions, and language.
Bacteria which retain the crystal violet stain when treated by Gram's method.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.

A group of antibiotics that contain 6-aminopenicillanic acid with a side chain attached to the 6-amino group. The penicillin nucleus is the chief structural requirement for biological activity. The side-chain structure determines many of the antibacterial and pharmacological characteristics. (Goodman and Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 8th ed, p1065)
A living entity.

Fundamental claims of patients, as expressed in statutes, declarations, or generally accepted moral principles. (Bioethics Thesaurus) The term is used for discussions of patient rights as a group of many rights, as in a hospital's posting of a list of patient rights.
